Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Mentoring Consortium at the Fourteenth International Conference on Autonomous Agents and Multi-Agent Systems (AAMAS-16)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
This award supports the participation of a select group of graduate students from US institutions at the International Conference on Autonomous Agents and Multiagent Systems (AAMAS 2016) and the accompanying doctoral mentoring consortium (DMC) to be held in Singapore, May 9-13, 2016. AAMAS is the premier conference on multi-agent systems. There is an increasing interest in research on agents worldwide because of the many technologies where agents are applicable including: information retrieval, electronic commerce, robotics, and education tasks among many others.

The DMC will be held before the start of the main conference, enabling the students to participate fully in all aspects of both the conference and the consortium. The activities at the DMC will involve interactions at multiple levels, where: 1) students will present and discuss their work with their peers; 2) students will hone their ability to succinctly describe their research in a one minute elevator pitch; 3) student research will be shown at a poster session, open to any conference attendee; and 4) students will be paired with a mentor from the senior program committee, who will meet with them privately during the conference to provide feedback on their dissertation topics. The DMC usually features a selection of invited speakers and culminates with a career advice panel with researchers from academia, industry, and government. During the course of the conference, students will have the opportunities to maximize international interactions and make new professional connections.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This grant partially supported the travel of 18 US doctoral student researchers to the premier international conference on autonomous agents and multiagent systems and their participation in the Doctoral Mentoring Consortium held in conjunction with it. The Fifteenth International Conference on Autonomous Agents and MultiAgent Systems (AAMAS 2016) was held in Singapore on May 913, 2016.

 

All students awarded travel funding participated in a Doctoral Mentoring Consortium in which they discussed their research to other student researchers and received feedback from a group of senior researchers. Students also attended the conference, which had a rich technical program complemented with an array of workshops, tutorials, and other events. In addition to individual student research talks, the 1-day consortium included:

  • An invited talk by Sandip Sen (U. Tulsa) on research program advice
  • Group lunch
  • An activity in which students practices their "elevator pitches"
  • A panel on career advice, which included Sam Barrett (Amazon Robotics), Edith Elkind (Oxford U.), Jeff Rosenschein (Hebrew U. of Jerusalem), and William Yeoh (New Mexico State University)

 

Participation in the doctoral consortium and the conference provided motivation for the students to continue in their research journey. It also helped them become members? of the international community of scholars, by making personal connections with other researchers from around the world. Student scholarship funds also make it possible for groups to send multiple students to attend the same conference, rather than simply having all conference papers presented by a senior researcher.

Scholarships were chosen on the basis of 

  • Match between their research topic and the topics covered in the Doctoral Mentoring Consortium;
  • Diversity of the participants, including ethnic, regional, and gender considerations;
  • Limited means to attached the Doctoral Mentoring Consortium;
  • Level of participation in the AAMAS conference; and
  • Time to anticipated graduation.

In addition to the PI, two additional members rounded out the 3-person panel that assigned scholarships: Katsuhide Fujita, from Tokyo University of Agriculture and Technology, and Koen Hindriks, from TU Delft.
